data.title: Market Voices: Airlines on gov't shutdown; Logan, Schmid on Fed rates
data.description:
Seeking Alpha's roundup of statements, announcements, and remarks that could impact markets, sectors, or individual stocks. 

  • United Airlines (UAL), Delta Air Lines (DAL) and American Airlines (AAL) are asking Congress to immediately pass a clean continuing resolution bill to reopen the U.S. government so that air traffic controllers can get paid.

“Missed paychecks only increases the stress on these essential workers, many of whom are already working mandatory overtime to keep our skies safe and secure,” Delta said in a statement, according to CNBC. 

“A prolonged shutdown will lead to more delays and cancellations — and the American people, especially during the busy holiday season, deserve better,” American Airlines said in a statement.

Vice President J.D. Vance and Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy met with the heads of the nation's leading airlines on Thursday to discuss the impact of the shutdown on air travel. 

  • Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas President Lorie Logan said Friday she didn't see a good reason for the Fed to cut interest rates earlier this week. 

"I would have preferred to hold interest rates steady at this week’s FOMC meeting," said Logan in a speech on Friday.

"The labor market remains balanced and cooling slowly. Inflation remains too high, taxing the budgets of businesses and families, and appears likely to exceed the FOMC’s 2 percent target for too much longer. This economic outlook didn’t call for cutting rates," she added.

  • Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City President Jeff Schmid also said he voted against the rate cut this week due to concerns about inflation. 

"At this week’s FOMC meeting I dissented against lowering the target range for the federal funds rate by 25 basis points. My preference would have been to leave the target range unchanged," Schmid said in a speech on Friday. 

"By my assessment, the labor market is largely in balance, the economy shows continued momentum, and inflation remains too high. I view the stance of policy as only modestly restrictive. In this context, I judged it appropriate to maintain the policy rate at this week’s meeting," he added.

data.title: Charter outlines 2025 peak capital spending and targets free cash flow growth amid intensified competition
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Charter Communications (CHTR) Q3 2025

Management View

  • CEO Christopher Winfrey highlighted that "we remained the fastest-growing mobile provider in the United States. We added nearly 500,000 Spectrum Mobile lines in the quarter and 2 million lines over the last 12 months, over 20% growth." Video customer losses improved to 70,000, described as "less than 1/4 of last year's third quarter losses." He noted that third quarter Internet customer losses were in line with last year and that revenue was down about 1% year-over-year, driven by customer losses and a challenging political advertising comparison. "Third quarter EBITDA declined by 1.5% year-over-year, essentially flat when excluding advertising," Winfrey added.
  • Winfrey stated, "We're leaving no stone unturned to drive customer and financial growth, including improved customer perception of our brand and products, growing mobile profitability and driving streaming video growth, all with the focus to drive connectivity revenue growth." He emphasized service and technology investments, including AI, and described new marketing approaches and offer expressions within the company's national pricing and packaging structure.
  • Winfrey detailed product advancements, including the upcoming launch of Advanced WiFi Complete in early 2026 and the Spectrum App Store. He also announced partnerships with Amazon and Nexar and a new immersive video partnership with Apple for Lakers games via the Apple Vision Pro.
  • CFO Jessica Fischer reported, "Including residential and small business, we lost 109,000 Internet customers in the third quarter, in line with last year's results, but lower when adjusted to remove last year's impact from ACP-related disconnects." Fischer noted, "In mobile, we added 493,000 lines with higher gross additions year-over-year, offset by disconnects on a larger base. Video customers declined by 70,000 versus a loss of 294,000 in 3Q of '24, with the improvement primarily driven by better connects year-over-year." She confirmed 52,000 net customer additions in the subsidized rural footprint, ongoing rural expansion, and the near completion of the BEAD bidding process.
  • Fischer stated, "Adjusted EBITDA declined by 1.5% year-over-year in the quarter and was essentially flat when excluding advertising." She also confirmed a decrease in programming costs by 6.5% and a 0.5% reduction in total operating expenses year-over-year.

Outlook

  • Fischer stated, "We expect 2025 full year EBITDA growth to be flat or marginally positive year-over-year with higher underlying growth absent the impact of political advertising." She added, "EBITDA growth in the fourth quarter will be pressured by at least as much as it was in the third quarter, given last year's political advertising strength and the same macro pressures we saw in the third quarter."
  • Capital expenditures for 2025 are expected to reach approximately $11.5 billion, which Fischer said is "lower than our original outlook of $12 billion, primarily as a result of some network evolution capital pushed into 2026." She affirmed that "2025 is the peak capital year, even if by a small margin."
  • Fischer reiterated, "even including the impact of the Cox transaction and associated integration capital, we expect total combined company capital expenditures to decline in the first full calendar year post close."

Financial Results

  • Fischer reported, "Third quarter free cash flow totaled $1.6 billion, in line with prior year, given higher CapEx offset by lower cash taxes and a more favorable change in cable working capital tied to CPE spend, some of which will reverse in 4Q."
  • Fischer stated, "Third quarter cash taxes totaled $53 million, and we expect full year cash tax payments to total approximately $1 billion."
  • The company finished the quarter with $95 billion in debt principal, a weighted average cost of debt at 5.2%, and annualized cash interest of $4.9 billion. Fischer disclosed, "During the quarter, we repurchased 7.6 million Charter shares and Charter Holdings common units, totaling $2.2 billion at an average price of $292 per share."
  • Fischer noted, "As of the end of the third quarter, our ratio of net debt to last 12-month adjusted EBITDA increased sequentially to 4.15x and stood at 4.23x pro forma for the pending Liberty Broadband transaction."

Q&A

  • Craig Moffett, MoffettNathanson LLC: Asked about broadband trends and improvement drivers. Winfrey replied that churn is better where there's a mobile relationship and more mobile lines per customer, and bundling reduces churn. He added, "The challenge that we're facing right now isn't so much on the churn side... The challenge we have is the operating environment remains competitive with new competitors and the macro environment that hasn't gotten better."
  • Benjamin Swinburne, Morgan Stanley: Asked about fourth quarter EBITDA guidance and competitive pricing. Fischer responded, "A few of those offers impacted ARPU a bit more than we had anticipated without driving the additional sales that we expected. We're pulling them from the market as of the beginning of November." Winfrey said, "Given this macro environment, we're not in a position to not pass through cost increases as they occur," and noted pricing discipline provides cushion.
  • Vikash Harlalka, New Street Research: Asked about marketing strategies. Winfrey explained, "These are just different marketing offer expressions to get to higher ARPU and higher margin per household, at the same time saving customers lots of money."
  • Jessica Reif Cohen, BofA Securities: Asked about the Cox acquisition and improvements in video conversion and retention. Winfrey said, "Our focus right now from a Cox perspective is a fewfold... Our goal here, it isn't to have positive video ads... but our goal is to make sure that we have a unique and differentiated product."
  • Michael Rollins, Citi: Asked about cost savings and expanding the addressable market. Winfrey highlighted an $8 billion annual cost to serve and described significant ongoing investments in AI and new B2B partnerships.
  • Peter Supino, Wolfe Research: Asked about debt structure and deleveraging. Fischer confirmed plans to move long-term target leverage to 3.5x to 4.0x post-Cox close, and said, "If it's prudent for us to make a move, we will."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed on growth outlook, competitive pressures, and capital allocation, with a slightly negative tone focused on revenue and EBITDA headwinds, as well as the impact of new competitors.
  • Management maintained a confident but cautious tone in prepared remarks, turning more defensive in Q&A, especially around sales trends and pricing. Winfrey said, "We're leaving no stone unturned to drive customer and financial growth," and "we're not standing still."
  • Compared to the previous quarter, current management sentiment was more cautious, especially regarding near-term growth and competitive headwinds. Analyst skepticism increased, with more probing on macro challenges and execution risk.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Internet customer losses remained comparable quarter-over-quarter, while video losses improved from 80,000 in Q2 to 70,000 in Q3.
  • Revenue shifted from slight growth in Q2 to a 1% year-over-year decline in Q3, with EBITDA moving from a 0.5% increase to a 1.5% decline. Free cash flow increased from $1 billion in Q2 to $1.6 billion in Q3.
  • The company reiterated its commitment to capital discipline, but acknowledged tougher EBITDA growth prospects in Q4 versus earlier indications.
  • Strategic priorities shifted slightly, with a greater emphasis on product bundling, digital marketing, and AI-driven cost efficiencies.
  • Management struck a more cautious tone, particularly around macroeconomic pressures and competitive dynamics, while analysts intensified their focus on operational risks.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited high competition for Internet customers, low move rates, increased mobile substitution, and expanded cellphone and fiber competition as risks.
  • Fischer mentioned pressure on ARPU growth and the negative impact of certain promotional offers.
  • Analysts raised concerns about growth sustainability, EBITDA pressure, and deleveraging in a challenging operating environment.

Final Takeaway

Charter Communications underscored its strategy of leveraging advanced products, improved marketing, and technology investments to offset a competitive and challenging macro environment. Management signaled that 2025 will be the peak year for capital spending and reaffirmed a shift toward free cash flow growth, even as near-term EBITDA and revenue face continued headwinds. The company remains focused on operational improvements, product innovation, and disciplined capital allocation to drive long-term shareholder value, with a particular emphasis on integrating the pending Cox transaction and scaling new service offerings.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Citigroup said in talks with Angolan bank to provide clearing services
data.description:
Citigroup (C) has held discussions with Africa's second-largest lender, Banco Fomento de Angola, or BFA, about offering dollar and euro clearing services, according to a media report on Friday.

BFA is exploring the option of establishing dollar and euro correspondent accounts with Citi (C), Bloomberg reported, citing people familiar with the matter. This was said to have followed a similar agreement recently finalized with Germany's Deutsche Bank (DB).

The private Angolan bank has also been in talks with JPMorgan Chase (JPM) over potential dollar and euro clearing service, one of the people added. 

The move could improve access to hard currency in a country that relies on imports and oil exports, the article said, and also help stabilize the kwanza (USD:AOA).

Neither Citigroup nor BFA immediately responded to Seeking Alpha's request for comment.

data.title: Nasdaq rallies higher on Amazon earnings; S&P 500 and Dow also climb
data.description:
Wall Street moved higher on Friday with the major indexes advancing as upbeat earnings from big tech companies fueled investor optimism.

Rising the most on the session was the tech focused Nasdaq Composite (COMP:IND) which was last up 1%. At the same time, the benchmark S&P 500 (SP500) was in the green by 0.5%, and the blue-chip Dow (DJI) climbed up 0.1%.

From a sector point of view, five of the 11 S&P segments advanced with Consumer Discretionary leading the way. At the other end of the spectrum, the Utilities space has suffered the most on the session so far.

U.S. Treasury yields ticked lower with the longer-end U.S. 10-year Treasury yield (US10Y) falling 1 basis point to 4.08% and the shorter-end U.S. 2-year Treasury yield (US2Y) moved down by 1 basis point to 3.60%.

"Indeed, just as the tech mood had soured yesterday, this morning that has mostly turned around following results from Apple and Amazon after the closing bell," Deutsche Bank's Jim Reid said.

Amazon (AMZN) soared 11.5% after it topped Q3 estimates with better-than-expected net sales, profits, and subscription revenues, and more importantly. It also delivered a beat on the company’s AWS, all of which offset compressed margins.

Apple (AAPL) traded near even after the tech giant reported fiscal fourth-quarter results that topped estimates.

On political news, the U.S. States reportedly cancelled a planned Budapest summit between President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin following Russia's firm stance on hardline demands regarding Ukraine.

As for oter stocks that are on the move, shares of First Solar (FSLR) have jumped up by 13.8%, while shares of DexCom (DXCM) plunged 16.4%.

data.title: Arcosa outlines 32% adjusted EBITDA growth target for 2025 while advancing portfolio optimization
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Arcosa, Inc. (ACA) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Antonio Carrillo, President and CEO, opened by highlighting "Q3 was a record quarter for Arcosa. We delivered double-digit revenue and adjusted EBITDA growth with all 3 segments contributing to our strong results. Revenue increased 27% and adjusted EBITDA grew 51%, both excluding the impact of the divested steel components business." He attributed this performance to the ongoing portfolio optimization strategy and the contribution of the $1.2 billion Stavola acquisition, reporting, "our record adjusted EBITDA margin of 21.8% was a 340 basis points improvement over the same period last year."

  • Carrillo emphasized the company's accelerated debt reduction, stating, "we ended the quarter with a leverage ratio of 2.4x, putting us 2 quarters ahead of our stated plan to return to our 2 to 2.5x leverage target within 18 months of the Stavola acquisition."

  • Gail Peck, Chief Financial Officer, reported, "third quarter revenues increased 46% and adjusted segment EBITDA increased 62%, which reflects record quarterly performance for the segment. Margin expanded by 300 basis points to 29.7%." She detailed that the aggregates business saw "freight-adjusted revenues increased 28% and adjusted cash gross profit increased 38% during the quarter, expanding margin by 330 basis points."

  • Peck also noted, "third quarter operating cash flow was $161 million, an increase of 19% year-over-year and up more than 150% sequentially," with free cash flow for the quarter at $134 million, up 25% year-over-year.

Outlook

  • Carrillo stated, "we have increased the midpoint of our 2025 adjusted EBITDA guidance range and anticipated 32% year-over-year growth, reflecting strong accretion from Stavola as well as double-digit organic expansion." He added full-year 2025 revenue guidance has been tightened to a range of $2.86 billion to $2.91 billion and adjusted EBITDA to a range of $575 million to $585 million.

  • For Construction Products, management "remain[s] on track for high single-digit pricing growth in aggregates." While year-to-date volumes were up 7%, the company "now expect[s] high single-digit volume growth, a slight step down from our prior guidance."

  • In Engineered Structures, "production in this facility is scheduled to begin in the second half of 2026. We expect our new galvanizing facility in Mexico to complete its first dip in the first quarter of 2026, which will improve our cost structure and enhance margin."

Financial Results

  • Revenue increased 27% year-over-year, and adjusted EBITDA grew 51%, both excluding divested steel components. Adjusted EBITDA margin reached 21.8%, an improvement of 340 basis points over last year.

  • Free cash flow for the quarter was $134 million, with operating cash flow at $161 million, and leverage ratio at 2.4x net debt to adjusted EBITDA.

  • Construction Products segment reported adjusted segment EBITDA of $150 million, with margin at 29.7%. Aggregates business saw an 18% total volume increase, mainly from Stavola, and organic volume growth for the first time in several quarters.

  • Engineered Structures reported segment revenues up 11% and adjusted segment EBITDA increased 29%, with margin expanding to 18.3%. Barge backlog rose 16% year-to-date to $326 million.

Q&A

  • Trey Grooms, Stephens: Asked for more detail on "puts and takes around the full year revenue and EBITDA guidance adjustments". Peck responded that the guidance adjustment reflects strong year-to-date performance and a "very small slight step down" in revenue due to softer organic construction volumes, while "we did raise the midpoint about $10 million. We now see $580 million of EBITDA for the year."

  • Grooms followed up on production downtime in legacy aggregates. Carrillo replied, "I think that's largely behind us," attributing past issues to unplanned equipment repairs.

  • Julio Romero, Sidoti: Asked about aggregate pricing outlook for 2026. Carrillo indicated optimism, "we're positive about where we're seeing demand, especially on the infrastructure side... Now that volume seems to be recovering, I think pricing should be something that we can continue to pass through to our customers."

  • Romero also asked about capital allocation. Carrillo said, "my goal would be to try to get lower in the range of 2 to 2.5x leverage," while also focusing on bolt-on acquisitions and organic investments.

  • Ian Zaffino, Oppenheimer: Inquired about wind tower orders and backlog acceleration. Carrillo explained, "our base case scenario is that these 2 years will accelerate as we get closer to end of 2027," and discussed the strategic move to bring backlog forward to capture customer demand before tax credits expire.

  • Garik Shmois, Loop Capital: Queried about barge replacement cycle. Carrillo asserted, "barges need to be replaced, both tank and hopper... we are pricing our barges like that."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts maintained a positive to slightly positive tone, focusing on guidance, capital allocation, and segment performance, often congratulating management on execution and inquiring about sustainability.

  • Management's tone was confident and occasionally defensive when discussing production issues, but overall optimistic about end market trends and strategic positioning, using phrases such as, "we are very good at building wind towers when we have a continued -- a very, very steady production cycle."

  • Compared to the previous quarter, both analysts and management expressed increased confidence, with fewer concerns about weather and more focus on growth and capital deployment.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance language shifted from maintaining the midpoint to raising the midpoint of adjusted EBITDA guidance and tightening the revenue range.

  • Strategic focus moved towards leveraging a stronger balance sheet for both organic and inorganic growth, while the previous quarter focused on integration and weather-related impacts.

  • Analysts' questions evolved from weather and pricing headwinds to demand drivers, capital deployment, and sustainability of new margin levels.

  • Management's sentiment improved, emphasizing execution, backlog visibility, and readiness for potential M&A.

  • Key metrics such as adjusted EBITDA growth, cash flow, and backlog all showed sequential improvements and heightened targets.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management identified production downtime in the aggregates business due to unplanned equipment repairs but stated these issues have been addressed.

  • Seasonal factors and weather dependency, especially in the Construction Products segment, remain a risk for fourth quarter performance.

  • The company is monitoring the transition of industry tax credits in wind towers, with Carrillo describing the next two years as a period that could "accelerate as we get closer to end of 2027."

Final Takeaway

Arcosa's third quarter results demonstrated strong revenue and EBITDA growth across all business segments, supported by portfolio optimization and the Stavola acquisition. Management raised the midpoint for 2025 adjusted EBITDA guidance to $580 million, targeting 32% growth, while maintaining a disciplined approach to capital allocation and expressing confidence in end market demand, backlog visibility, and long-term growth potential for core businesses.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: First Solar shines as Q3 sales soar; set to open another U.S. factory
data.description:
First Solar (FSLR) +14.4% in Friday's trading after posting mixed Q3 results, with analysts citing higher than expected module shipments and narrowed full-year guidance that was better than feared given the regulatory backdrop.

Q3 net profit rose to $455.9 million, or $4.24/share, from $312.9 million, or $2.91/share, in the year-earlier quarter, and revenues surged 79% Y/Y to $1.59 billion, as the company sold a record-high 5.3 GW of modules, including 2.5 GW made at its U.S. production facilities.

Q3 gross bookings totaled 2.7 GW, and its contracted sales backlog amounted to 53.7 GW and was valued at $16.4 billion.

First Solar (FSLR) said it now expects FY 2025 revenues of $4.95 billion-$5.2 billion, compared with prior guidance of $4.9 billion-$5.7 billion, with earnings of $14.00-$15.00/share, narrowed from $13.50-$16.50 previously, reflecting "reduced international volumes sold due to customer terminations, partially offset by termination payments," the company said during its earnings conference call.

The company also also lowered the top end of its guidance range for volumes sold to 17.4 GW from 19.3 GW, while keeping the low end unchanged at 16.7 GW.

Citi analyst Vikram Bagri, who rates First Solar (FSLR) as a Buy with a $300 price target, said the Q3 results are positive, with "higher than anticipated bookings and a lower than feared guidance cut," saying "management's patient approach to bookings, strategic actions and resolution of near-term headwinds should lead to strong earnings growth and trading multiple compression over the next two years."

Susquehanna's Charles Minervino maintained his Positive rating on First Solar (FSLR) and raised his PT to $285 from $273, saying he continues to like the company "given its advantageous U.S. manufacturing position and growing headwinds (Section 232 tariffs, AD/CVD investigation, FEOC restriction) on the import of crystalline silicon modules, which should benefit FSLR’s vertically integrated domestic supply chain."

First Solar (FSLR) also unveiled plans to establish a new 3.7 GW manufacturing facility in the U.S., with production expected to start at the end of 2026 and ramp up through H1 2027.

No location has been disclosed for the $300 million manufacturing facility, but the company said it will onshore the finishing of Series 6 modules started at international factories.

data.title: FTAI Infrastructure targets $460M annual EBITDA as Wheeling acquisition and gas production boost growth prospects
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: FTAI Infrastructure Inc. (FIP) Q3 2025

Management View

  • Kenneth Nicholson, CEO & President, highlighted a transformative quarter with the acquisition of Wheeling & Lake Erie Railway, stating the transaction "sets the stage for significant growth in our Rail segment in the quarters to come." He further noted that gas production began in West Virginia, producing over 100,000 MMBtu per day, which exceeds the power plant's consumption.

  • Nicholson reported strong financial performance: "Adjusted EBITDA for the quarter was $70.9 million, up 55% from $45.9 million last quarter and nearly double adjusted EBITDA year-over-year." He pointed out that these results included only five weeks of Wheeling's results and just under five weeks from West Virginia gas production.

  • Nicholson expressed confidence in exceeding $450 million of adjusted EBITDA on an annual basis, excluding organic growth or new wins, and stated, "Our $460 million annual target excludes several important opportunities, including a number of meaningful new revenue opportunities."

  • Nicholson explained that the company intends to pursue strategic alternatives for Long Ridge, including a potential monetization: "It is a great asset and a great market environment to be exploring a sale."

  • Regarding capital structure, Nicholson described a plan to refinance the existing parent level credit facility with a new long-term bond issuance before year-end, positioning the company for deleveraging.

Outlook

  • Nicholson stated that the full impact of Wheeling and West Virginia gas production will be reflected in Q4 and beyond, with expectations for continued growth in reported results.

  • The company anticipates Long Ridge achieving its $160 million annual EBITDA run rate in the fourth quarter.

  • Nicholson increased financial targets for the combined Transtar and Wheeling platform, now expecting "EBITDA for the combined Transtar and Wheeling of at least $220 million run rate by the end of 2026, up from our $200 million original estimate."

  • The company expects to generate additional cash flow from new business at Repauno and Jefferson, which will be available for parent debt service and reinvestment or deleveraging.

Financial Results

  • Rail segment revenue was $61.7 million and adjusted EBITDA was $29.1 million in Q3, up from $42.1 million revenue and $20.7 million EBITDA in Q2.

  • Wheeling generated approximately $20 million of adjusted EBITDA for the full quarter; Nicholson said, "Volumes and revenues at the Wheeling were up approximately 10% versus the company's second quarter and EBITDA was up 20%."

  • Long Ridge reported EBITDA of $35.7 million, up from $23 million in Q2, with a capacity factor of 96%. Production exceeded 100,000 MMBtu per day compared to the plant's requirement of 70,000 MMBtu per day.

  • Jefferson posted $21.1 million in revenue and $11 million in adjusted EBITDA, closely matching the previous quarter. Agreements in place are expected to add $20 million of annual EBITDA in the coming months.

  • At Repauno, Phase 2 construction is fully funded, and contracts plus a letter of intent represent $80 million of annual EBITDA once operational. Phase 3 received a key construction permit this month.

Q&A

  • Giuliano Anderes-Bologna, Compass Point: Asked about SG&A expectations as the company transitions to an operating model. Nicholson responded, "Our G&A really is more of a fixed expense... it should stay relatively flat."

  • Anderes-Bologna: Asked about synergies from integrating Wheeling and Transtar. Nicholson cited "$20 million of cost savings and efficiencies," highlighting combined purchasing power and elimination of redundancies, and described network optimization and expanded customer reach as further benefits.

  • Anderes-Bologna: Inquired about additional rail acquisitions. Nicholson replied, "I think bigger is better... we're even better positioned to go out and buy more railroads."

  • Brian Mckenna, Citizens: Asked about the timing for STB approval for Wheeling acquisition. Nicholson indicated that year-end is a reasonable expectation, adding, "I have a decent sense that at the STB, this is a priority for them."

  • Mckenna: Asked about Rail segment cash generation and use. Nicholson estimated normalized cash flow of about $35 million, noting, "All of that cash will be available to shoot up to our parent, and it will be used initially for debt service."

  • Gregory Lewis, BTIG: Asked about Repauno Phase 3 next steps and CapEx. Nicholson estimated $200 million to build one cavern, generating about $70 million to $80 million of annual EBITDA, with construction likely to take 2–3 years.

  • Lewis: Asked about Long Ridge sale structure. Nicholson stated, "I would expect that the ultimate transaction involve a sale of the entire business, the entire asset, the entire business, the gas, the power plant, the land."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts expressed positive sentiment, repeatedly acknowledging strong performance, momentum, and strategic clarity, with questions focusing on synergy realization and growth plans.

  • Management maintained a confident tone, particularly in discussing financial performance, growth targets, and integration plans. Nicholson used phrases such as "we have high confidence" and "we are excited to keep up the effort."

  • Compared to the previous quarter, management’s confidence appeared higher, supported by improved results and upwardly revised targets, while analysts’ tone remained constructive and focused on execution.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • EBITDA surged from $45.9 million in Q2 to $70.9 million in Q3. The Wheeling acquisition moved from announcement and planning in Q2 to having a partial financial impact in Q3.

  • The combined Transtar and Wheeling EBITDA target was raised from $200 million to $220 million by year-end 2026.

  • Strategic focus in Q3 centered on integrating Wheeling, monetizing Long Ridge, and advancing Repauno construction, compared to Q2’s emphasis on closing the Wheeling deal and finalizing financing.

  • Analysts’ focus shifted from transaction details to execution and integration, while management’s tone became more assertive and forward-looking.

Risks and Concerns

  • Nicholson acknowledged uncertainty around the timing of STB approval due to the federal government shutdown but maintained expectations for a timely outcome.

  • The company faces execution risks in integrating Wheeling and realizing synergies, as well as potential delays in Repauno construction and Long Ridge monetization.

  • Management outlined plans to maintain stable SG&A, leverage existing cash flow for deleveraging, and pursue strategic alternatives to mitigate risks.

Final Takeaway

Management underscored a pivotal third quarter with the successful Wheeling acquisition, initiation of West Virginia gas production, and a material uplift in financial performance and targets. With integration underway, stable cost structures, and new revenue streams set to fully materialize in Q4 and beyond, the company projects robust adjusted EBITDA growth, supported by continued strategic initiatives across its business segments.

Read the full Earnings Call Transcript

data.title: Lumen Technologies slips despite beating Q3 estimates
data.description:
Shares of Lumen Technologies (LUMN) slipped nearly 9% on Friday, despite the company beat EPS as well as revenue estimates for the third quarter.

The telecom and networking company reported Q3 non-GAAP EPS of -$0.20, beating consensus by $0.07, while revenue of $3.09 billion was $50 million higher than consensus.

However, shares dropped as the company posted a wider net loss of $621 million for the third quarter versus $148 million a year ago, with loss per share widening to $0.62 from $0.15. The company’s revenue also declined 4% Y/Y to $3.09 billion, while operating expenses rose 3% to $3.20 billion, reflecting ongoing cost pressures.

During the Q3 earnings call, Christopher Stansbury, Executive VP & CFO, reiterated, "we expect fourth quarter revenue to be negatively impacted by additional declines in public sector Harvest revenue as that revenue returns to more normalized levels, similar to the third quarter of 2024."

For FY 2025, Lumen maintains its capital expenditure guidance at $4.1 billion to $4.3 billion and its full year free cash flow guidance at $1.2 billion to $1.4 billion, including an anticipated $400 million tax refund.

data.title: Why it is time to look into international markets – strategist
data.description:
Investors should look beyond U.S. markets (SP500), (COMP:IND), (DJI) for significant growth opportunities in the coming years, according to Mary Ann Bartels, chief investment strategist at Sanctuary Wealth.

In an interview with CNBC, Bartels emphasized her firm’s strategic focus on international exposure, stating investors should look into non-U.S. markets including emerging markets, and add exposure there.

The weakening of the dollar (DXY) has provided an additional boost to international investment returns, though Bartels predicts potential dollar strengthening ahead.

“I think you can get a substantial rally in the dollar (DXY) and a weakening in the euro,” she said, suggesting currency dynamics will play an important role in investment strategies moving forward.

Bartels painted an optimistic picture for global equity markets, particularly highlighting opportunities outside the U.S. “When we’re looking at Europe (VGK), (IEV), (IEUR), when we’re looking at emerging markets (EEM) and parts of the other Asian markets (ASEA), (EEMA), (AAXJ), you’re just entering a new secular bull market,” she explained, distinguishing these regions from the more mature market cycle in the U.S.

The strategist expressed extraordinary confidence in global market performance over the medium term.

“I think the runway for equity performance, out for the next five years plus, is quite extraordinary,” Bartels said, suggesting markets have not fully accounted for the earnings potential that will emerge on a global scale beyond just the U.S.

Technology and AI remain central to Bartels’s investment thesis, with semiconductors (SMH), (SOXX), (XSD) driving global economic transformation.

“AI is the new transformation and build out on a global scale that we really haven’t seen since the U.S. built out its railroads or had the invention of the steam engine,” she said, emphasizing that this trend will continue to drive markets “going into the end of the decade.”

More Emerging Market ETFs: (IEMG), (VWO), (EEM), (SPEM), (SCHE), and (AVEM).

China ETFs: (KWEB), (PGJ), (CQQQ), (FXI), (GXC), (MCHI), (FLCH), (CNYA), (ASHR), and (YINN).

Canada ETFs: (EWC), (FXC), (FLCA), and (BBCA).

Mexico ETFs: (EWW), FLMX), and (MEXX).

data.title: Standex raises fiscal 2026 sales outlook to $110M+ growth, driven by Grid and new products momentum
data.description:
Earnings Call Insights: Standex International Corporation (SXI) Q1 2026

Management View

  • David Dunbar, Chairman, President & CEO, opened by stating that "our first quarter performance provided a strong start to the fiscal year, positioning us well to exceed our previously provided guidance of greater than $100 million of incremental sales in fiscal year 2026, which includes organic growth in our core businesses as well as the full year impact of acquisitions." He highlighted new product sales growth of more than 35% to approximately $14.5 million and sales in fast-growth markets reaching approximately $62 million, representing 30% of total sales. Orders of approximately $226 million marked the highest quarterly intake ever. Dunbar announced, "we are raising our fiscal year 2026 sales outlook. Barring unforeseen economics, global trade or tariffs-related disruptions we now expect revenue to grow by over $110 million, $10 million more than we communicated last quarter." He also detailed the renaming of Amran/Narayan as Standex Electronics Grid and noted that operations have started in Croatia and Mexico.
  • CFO Ademir Sarcevic reported, "total revenue increased approximately 27.6% year-on-year to $217.4 million... adjusted operating margin increased 210 basis points year-on-year to 19.1%." Sarcevic added, "adjusted earnings per share increased 8.2% year-on-year to $1.99. Net cash provided by operating activities was $16.8 million... Capital expenditures were $6.4 million... we generated fiscal first quarter free cash flow of $10.4 million."

Outlook

  • Management raised the fiscal 2026 sales outlook, expecting revenue to grow by over $110 million, citing strong momentum from new product sales and fast-growth market expansion, particularly Standex Electronics Grid. The company expects new product sales to contribute approximately 300 basis points of incremental sales growth and plans to launch more than 15 new products in fiscal 2026. Sales from fast-growth markets are now expected to grow over 45% year-on-year and exceed $270 million. Dunbar stated, "on a year-on-year basis, in fiscal second quarter 2026, we expect significantly higher revenue driven by mid-single-digit organic growth and contributions from recent acquisitions and similar adjusted operating margin due to higher growth investments and less favorable product mix."

Financial Results

  • Standex reported consolidated revenue of $217.4 million, an increase of 27.6% year-on-year, with a 26.6% benefit from recent acquisitions. Adjusted operating income increased 43.3%, and adjusted earnings per share rose 8.2% to $1.99. Free cash flow was $10.4 million, and the net leverage ratio improved to 2.4x. Electronics segment revenue was $110.6 million, up 42.2% year-on-year, with an adjusted operating margin of 28.8%. Engineering Technologies revenue increased 45.6% to $29.9 million, while Scientific revenue increased 9.9% to $19.5 million. Engraving revenue rose 7.4% to $35.8 million, and Specialty Solutions revenue was $21.7 million. The company declared a $0.34 per share dividend, a 6.3% year-on-year increase.

Q&A

  • Christopher Moore, CJS Securities, Inc.: Asked about further optimization and focus areas. Dunbar responded that the "greatest value creation will come from realizing the potential of the organic growth initiatives... that momentum will get us there."
  • Moore: Sought details on standout new products. Dunbar highlighted electronics products for relays and test applications, and Scientific’s ultra-low temperature freezer.
  • Moore: Inquired about Amran/Narayan growth sustainability. Dunbar stated, "we are not seeing a slowdown in growth... the end market remains strong, driven by electrification, modernization of grid and continued spend in data centers."
  • Ross Sparenblek, William Blair: Focused on Electronics momentum and legacy business order growth. Dunbar noted strong bookings in defense and test and measurement, with strength across geographies and product lines. Sarcevic confirmed, "book-to-bill for all of those businesses has been over 1."
  • Sparenblek: Asked about margin expectations and cost savings. Sarcevic explained margin improvement will be offset by growth investments, but "there should be some natural lift there."
  • Michael Shlisky, D.A. Davidson: Asked about Electronics branding. Dunbar described the rebranding to Grid, Edge, and Detect for business clarity and expansion.
  • Shlisky: Queried on government impact. Dunbar saw no recent rapid changes but acknowledged NIH funding cuts affecting Scientific.
  • Gary Prestopino, Barrington Research: Asked about fast-growth drivers and new product overlap. Dunbar clarified about half of fast-growth sales relate to data centers and grid, and new products will increasingly target fast-growth markets.
  • Matt Koranda, ROTH Capital Partners: Inquired about Amran/Narayan book-to-bill and portfolio simplification. Dunbar and Sarcevic indicated book-to-bill above 1 and that simplification actions are ongoing, with financial flexibility building for future acquisitions.
  • Sparenblek (follow-up): Questioned Engraving margin potential. Sarcevic stated, "that 20% margin number... is within reach, and we feel very confident that when the market comes back with some strength that we'll be able to surpass the 20% as well."

Sentiment Analysis

  • Analysts pressed on growth sustainability, margin realization, new product impact, and portfolio optimization, with a neutral to slightly positive tone, probing for future upside and execution risks.
  • Management’s tone was confident and optimistic during prepared remarks and Q&A, emphasizing strong order momentum, successful integration, and growth investments. Dunbar stated, "we see no slowdown right now," and Sarcevic highlighted, "the momentum continues."
  • Compared to last quarter, the sentiment remains confident, with management providing more specific upward revisions to guidance and continued positive outlook on growth drivers, while analysts continue to probe sustainability and operational execution.

Quarter-over-Quarter Comparison

  • Guidance for fiscal 2026 sales was raised from over $100 million to over $110 million in incremental growth, reflecting increased confidence from new product and fast-growth market momentum. Sales in fast-growth markets and new product launches are both revised upward, with fast-growth sales now expected to exceed $270 million, compared to $265 million previously. Management’s tone remains confident, building on prior quarter’s record performance, while analysts’ focus remains on validating the sustainability of growth and margin expansion. The strategic focus on new products and grid technologies continues, but with greater emphasis on geographic expansion and operational execution. Margin expectations are tempered by increased investment and product mix, compared to the prior quarter’s focus on margin expansion.

Risks and Concerns

  • Management cited potential risks from unforeseen economic, global trade or tariffs-related disruptions. Scientific remains impacted by NIH funding cuts, with management not expecting recovery in that segment. Tariff and sourcing risks are being managed through alternative sourcing and pricing strategies. Analysts continued to raise questions about sustainability of growth, capacity utilization, and the impact of funding and macroeconomic factors.

Final Takeaway

Standex International Corporation began fiscal 2026 with accelerating momentum from new product launches and robust growth in fast-growth markets, particularly within its renamed Standex Electronics Grid business. Management raised its full-year sales outlook to more than $110 million in incremental revenue, driven by continued integration of acquisitions, capacity expansions in Croatia and Mexico, and record order intake. The company remains focused on executing its organic growth initiatives, investing in product innovation, and optimizing its business portfolio while closely monitoring macroeconomic and funding risks.
